query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
13 Ne l’ora che comincia i tristi lai 14 la rondinella presso a la mattina, 15 forse a memoria de’ suo’ primi guai,
16 e che la mente nostra, peregrina 17 più da la carne e men da’ pensier presa, 18 a le sue visïon quasi è divina,
19 in sogno mi parea veder sospesa 20 un’aguglia nel ciel con penne d’oro, 21 con l’ali aperte e a calare intesa;
22 ed esser mi parea là dove fuoro 23 abbandonati i suoi da Ganimede, 24 quando fu ratto al sommo consistoro.
query.result:
**English:**
13 At the hour when the swallow begins its sad songs 14 near the morning, 15 perhaps in memory of its former woes,
16 and when our mind, a pilgrim, 17 less taken by the flesh and more by thoughts, 18 is almost divine in its visions,
19 in a dream I seemed to see suspended 20 an eagle in the sky with golden feathers, 21 with its wings spread and intent on descending;
22 and I seemed to be where Ganymede 23 had abandoned his own people, 24 when he was snatched up to the highest consistory.
**Cornish:**
13 Y’n eur pan vyn an avalow a wra dalleth y goweth trist, 14 ogas dhe’n vreten, 15 efalla mar a-ves an kov a’y boesow kynsa.
16 Ha pan vyn an menes ni, pererin, 17 moy kemeres gans an kik ha moy kemeres gans an powesow, 18 a wra dalleth dhewinel y’n y visyons.
19 Y’n hunros vyn my a wra gweles war-benn 20 onen er a’n ayr gans esel a our, 21 gans y esel ager ha dalleth dalleth dhesel.
22 Ha my a wra gweles vyn y’n le may Ganimedes 23 a wra gweres y dus a-ves, 24 pan vyn ev dalleth kemerys dhe’n konsistri moy uhella.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
25 Fra me pensava: ‘Forse questa fiede 26 pur qui per uso, e forse d’altro loco 27 disdegna di portarne suso in piede’.
query.result:
**English:**
25 Within myself I thought: ‘Perhaps this one strikes 26 only here out of habit, and perhaps it disdains 27 to carry us up higher on its feet’.
**Cornish:**
25 Yn-mes vyn my a wra poesya: ‘Efalla henna a wra dalleth 26 pur ama rag usadow, ha efalla a-ves le aral le 27 a wra dalleth disdein a’n fordha ni war y tros’.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
28 Poi mi parea che, poi rotata un poco, 29 terribil come folgor discendesse, 30 e me rapisse suso infino al foco.
query.result:
**English:**
28 Then it seemed to me that, after circling a little, 29 it descended terribly like lightning, 30 and snatched me up to the fire.
**Cornish:**
28 Wosa henna my a wra gweles ev, wosa ev dalleth troyllel byghan, 29 ev a wra dalleth diskennans dhewinel avel un folgor, 30 ha my a wra dalleth kemerel war-benn dhe’n tan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
31 Ivi parea che ella e io ardesse; 32 e sì lo ’ncendio imaginato cosse, 33 che convenne che ’l sonno si rompesse.
query.result:
**English:**
31 There it seemed that she and I were burning; 32 and the imagined fire burned so fiercely, 33 that the sleep had to break.
**Cornish:**
31 Ama my a wra gweles ev ha my a wra dalleth loski; 32 ha an tan a wra dalleth loski dhewinel, 33 henna a wra dalleth rekis an kows dhesel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
34 Non altrimenti Achille si riscosse, 35 li occhi svegliati rivolgendo in giro 36 e non sappiendo là dove si fosse,
37 quando la madre da Chirón a Schiro 38 trafuggò lui dormendo in le sue braccia, 39 là onde poi li Greci il dipartiro;
40 che mi scoss’ io, sì come da la faccia 41 mi fuggì ’l sonno, e diventa’ ismorto, 42 come fa l’uom che, spaventato, agghiaccia.
query.result:
**English:**
34 Not otherwise did Achilles start up, 35 turning his awakened eyes around, 36 and not knowing where he was,
37 when his mother carried him off from Chiron at Scyros, 38 stealing him away while he slept in her arms, 39 from where the Greeks later took him away;
40 than I started up, as sleep fled from my face, 41 and I turned pale, 42 like a man who is frozen with fear.
**Cornish:**
34 Na dheffar dhe Achilles a wra dalleth sevel, 35 ylagas ylagas dalleth troyllel a-dro, 36 ha na wodhes le may ev o.
37 Pan vyn y vam a wra dalleth kemerel ev a-ves Chirón dhe Schiro, 38 a wra dalleth kemerel ev war-benn y brassa pan vyn ev a wra dalleth kows, 39 a-dhia may wosa an Greks a wra dalleth kemerel ev.
40 Henna o vyn a wra dalleth sevel, avel pan vyn an kows a wra dalleth kerhes 41 a-ves y hon fas, ha vyn a wra dalleth mosorti, 42 avel un den a wra dalleth kelli, a wra dalleth sevel avel un garm.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
43 Dallato m’era solo il mio conforto, 44 e ’l sole er’ alto già più che due ore, 45 e ’l viso m’era a la marina torto.
query.result:
**English:**
43 Beside me was only my comfort, 44 and the sun was already more than two hours high, 45 and my face was turned towards the sea.
**Cornish:**
43 Y’n tu a vyn o wra’n unnik henna a wra dalleth’m gorra, 44 ha’n howl o wra moy uhella ages dew eur, 45 ha’m fas o wra dalleth troyllel dhe’n mor.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
49 Tu se’ omai al purgatorio giunto: 50 vedi là il balzo che ’l chiude dintorno; 51 vedi l’entrata là ’ve par digiunto.
query.result:
**English:**
49 You have now reached purgatory: 50 see there the cliff that encloses it all around; 51 see the entrance there where it seems to be broken.
**Cornish:**
49 Wrug a wra dalleth dalleth dhe’n purgatory: 50 gweles ama an balji a wra dalleth y kovra a-dro; 51 gweles an entre a-le may ev a wra dalleth gweles dhejunyes.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
52 Dianzi, ne l’alba che procede al giorno, 53 quando l’anima tua dentro dormia, 54 sovra li fiori ond’ è là giù addorno
55 venne una donna, e disse: “I’ son Lucia; 56 lasciatemi pigliar costui che dorme; 57 sì l’agevolerò per la sua via”.
query.result:
**English:**
52 Just now, in the dawn that precedes the day, 53 when your soul was sleeping within, 54 over the flowers with which it is adorned down there,
55 a woman came and said: “I am Lucia; 56 let me take this sleeping man; 57 I will help him on his way”.
**Cornish:**
52 Mes ow, y’n gwawr a wra dhe’n jydh, 53 pan o eneval o kollas ow tewlel, 54 war-tu an bleujyn ow tysornsi y’n-nans,
55 on benen benyn, ha leverel: “My a’n Lucia; 56 gansowgh vy dhe gemeres an den-ma ow tewlel; 57 vy a’n gal owth eval war y fordh”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
58 Sordel rimase e l’altre genti forme; 59 ella ti tolse, e come ’l dì fu chiaro, 60 sen venne suso; e io per le sue orme.
query.result:
**English:**
58 Sordello remained, and the other noble forms; 59 she took you away, and when it was daylight, 60 she came up; and I followed in her footsteps.
**Cornish:**
58 Sordel a veu, ha’n dus a dusow nobyl; 59 hyn a’th kemer, ha pan o veu an jydh gleer, 60 hyn a dheuth war-nans; ha my a’m sewyes y’n fosow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
61 Qui ti posò, ma pria mi dimostraro 62 li occhi suoi belli quella intrata aperta; 63 poi ella e ’l sonno ad una se n’andaro».
query.result:
**English:**
61 Here she put you down, but first 62 her beautiful eyes showed me that open entrance; 63 then she and sleep went away together.
**Cornish:**
61 Ama hi a’th ros, mes kyns henna 62 ylagasow brav a dhiskwedhas an fordh agoredh; 63 wosa henna ha’n kows a veu yn-nans”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
64 A guisa d’uom che ’n dubbio si raccerta 65 e che muta in conforto sua paura, 66 poi che la verità li è discoperta,
67 mi cambia’ io; e come sanza cura 68 vide me ’l duca mio, su per lo balzo 69 si mosse, e io di rietro inver’ l’altura.
query.result:
**English:**
64 Like a man who regains his confidence in doubt, 65 and changes his fear into comfort, 66 once the truth is revealed to him,
67 so I changed; and when my leader saw me without worry, 68 he moved up the cliff, 69 and I followed him towards the heights.
**Cornish:**
64 Dell yw den a wra yn-nans yn-ometh, 65 ha’n wra y ewn yn-nans yn-ometh, 66 wosa henna gwir a veu dhiskwedhes dhys,
67 hemma fi a wra chanjyes; ha pan welas ow thuk 68 vy heb sor, war-nans an bal, 69 ef a veu movyes, ha my a’m sewyes dhe dhe’n ughella.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
70 Lettor, tu vedi ben com’ io innalzo 71 la mia matera, e però con più arte 72 non ti maravigliar s’io la rincalzo.
query.result:
**English:**
70 Reader, you see well how I elevate 71 my subject matter, and therefore do not be surprised 72 if I reinforce it with more artistry.
**Cornish:**
70 Lymner, te wel ytho dell vy a wra’m ughella 71 ow mater, ha ragwynn na’th omma moy 72 na’th omma gwella vy a wra’m gallos.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
73 Noi ci appressammo, ed eravamo in parte 74 che là dove pareami prima rotto, 75 pur come un fesso che muro diparte,
76 vidi una porta, e tre gradi di sotto 77 per gire ad essa, di color diversi, 78 e un portier ch’ancor non facea motto.
query.result:
**English:**
73 We approached, and we were at a point 74 where what had seemed broken to me before, 75 just like a crack that divides a wall,
76 I saw a gate, and three steps below 77 to go to it, of different colors, 78 and a doorkeeper who still said nothing.
**Cornish:**
73 Ni a wra dalleth, ha ni a veu yn rann 74 le may hemma kyns o kyns o kyns 75 dell dell dell dell dell,
76 vy a welas fordh, ha tri gres yn-nans 77 rag an fordh, a livrow dyffrans, 78 ha portier na veu leveres ger.

**English:**
79 And as I opened my eyes more and more, 80 I saw him sitting on the highest step, 81 with such a face that I could not bear it;
82 and he had a naked sword in his hand, 83 which reflected the rays towards us, 84 so that I often raised my face in vain.
**Cornish:**
79 Ha dell vy a wra agori ow lagasew moy ha moy, 80 vy a welas ow sedhes war an gres ughella, 81 dell dell dell dell dell,
82 ha kledha nans o veu yn y dowr, 83 owth omma gweli an gweli dhe’n-nans, 84 vy a wra trohe ow eneval yn-ometh.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
85 «Dite costinci: che volete voi?», 86 cominciò elli a dire, «ov’ è la scorta? 87 Guardate che ’l venir sù non vi nòi».
query.result:
**English:**
85 “Tell me from there: what do you want?”, 86 he began to say, “where is your guide? 87 Beware that coming up here does not harm you”.
**Cornish:**
85 “Leverel owth hemma: pyth yw ow holon?”, 86 ef a dhalleth leverel, “piw yw an skorta? 87 Gwylyow na’th dos ow tos dhe’n-nans”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
88 «Donna del ciel, di queste cose accorta», 89 rispuose ’l mio maestro a lui, «pur dianzi 90 ne disse: “Andate là: quivi è la porta”».
query.result:
**English:**
88 “Lady of heaven, aware of these things”, 89 my master replied to him, “just now 90 she said: “Go there: that is the gate””.
**Cornish:**
88 “Benyn a’n nef, owth omma gweli an traow-ma”, 89 ow mester a leveres dhys, “mes owth omma leverel 90 “Mos dhe’n-nans: ena yw an fordh””.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
91 «Ed ella i passi vostri in bene avanzi», 92 ricominciò il cortese portinaio: 93 «Venite dunque a’ nostri gradi innanzi».
query.result:
**English:**
91 “And may she advance your steps for good”, 92 the courteous gatekeeper began again: 93 “Come then before our steps”.
**Cornish:**
91 “Ha henna rag owth passow yn-nans yn-ometh”, 92 an portier kurteys a dhalleth leverel: 93 “Dosow dhe’n-nans dhe’n-nans dhe’n-nans”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
94 Là ne venimmo; e lo scaglion primaio 95 bianco marmo era sì pulito e terso, 96 ch’io mi specchiai in esso qual io paio.
query.result:
**English:**
94 There we came; and the first step 95 was of white marble, so polished and smooth, 96 that I saw myself in it as I appear.
**Cornish:**
94 Eno deuthan ni; ha'n kynsa pellder 95 avel marbel gwyn o se glan ha gloyw, 96 henna wrug y'm gweles onan vy dheuth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
97 Era il secondo tinto più che perso, 98 d’una petrina ruvida e arsiccia, 99 crepata per lo lungo e per traverso.
query.result:
**English:**
97 It was the second dusk, more than lost, 98 of a rough and scorched stone, 99 cracked lengthwise and crosswise.**Cornish:**
97 An eyl esa an nessa nessa kollet, 98 a-dhyworth karrek garow ha losk, 99 torrys a-hys ha a-ledan.**

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
100 Lo terzo, che di sopra s’ammassiccia, 101 porfido mi parea, sì fiammeggiante 102 come sangue che fuor di vena spiccia.
query.result:
**English:**
100 The third, which masses above, 101 seemed to me to be porphyry, so flaming 102 like blood that spurts out of a vein.**Cornish:**
100 An nessa, a-ugh a-ugh warbarth, 101 a-hwelow porfiri dhom, kenjynn tanow, 102 avel gwydh a-spryng a-ves a-ugh gwyth.**

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
103 Sovra questo tenëa ambo le piante 104 l’angel di Dio sedendo in su la soglia 105 che mi sembiava pietra di diamante.
query.result:
**English:**
103 Upon this, the angel of God was sitting, 104 with both feet planted, on the threshold 105 that seemed to me to be a diamond.**Cornish:**
103 Warbarth hemma, an el an Dhew a-sesa, 104 gans an dhewlagas war an fordh, 105 a-hwelow dhom dhymmyn dhom.**

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
106 Per li tre gradi sù di buona voglia 107 mi trasse il duca mio, dicendo: «Chiedi 108 umilemente che ’l serrame scioglia».
query.result:
**English:**
106 Up the three steps, with good will, 107 my leader drew me, saying: “Ask 108 humbly that he unbolt the lock”.**Cornish:**
106 A-ugh an tri gorhel, gans kalon da, 107 y'm gorragh an myghtern, ow leverel: 108 “Govyth yn isel dhe dhaskyla an ser.”**

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
109 Divoto mi gittai a’ santi piedi; 110 misericordia chiesi e ch’el m’aprisse, 111 ma tre volte nel petto pria mi diedi.
query.result:
**English:**
109 Devoutly I threw myself at the holy feet; 110 I asked for mercy and for him to open for me, 111 but first I struck myself three times in the chest.**Cornish:**
109 Devot a-wrug y'm hwyta dhe'n treys sans, 110 kerensa y'm gorragh ha dhe'n gorragh dhom dhegor, 111 mes tri gweyth y'm gorragh yn kledha kyns.**

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
112 Sette P ne la fronte mi descrisse 113 col punton de la spada, e «Fa che lavi, 114 quando se’ dentro, queste piaghe» disse.
query.result:
**English:**
112 Seven P’s he inscribed on my forehead 113 with the point of his sword, and said: “Make sure to wash 114 these wounds when you are inside”.**Cornish:**
112 Seyth P war y'n tal y'm skrifas, 113 gans boynt an kledha, ha leverel: “Gwreugh 114 dhe wul henna, pan vo bys y'n mes.”**

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
115 Cenere, o terra che secca si cavi, 116 d’un color fora col suo vestimento; 117 e di sotto da quel trasse due chiavi.
query.result:
**English:**
115 Ashes, or earth dug up when dry, 116 would be the color of his clothing; 117 and from underneath it he drew two keys.**Cornish:**
115 Losow, po tir ow tosow a-sech, 116 a via an keth a'y dhillad; 117 ha a-woles hemma y'n gorragh dew gelwys.**

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
118 L’una era d’oro e l’altra era d’argento; 119 pria con la bianca e poscia con la gialla 120 fece a la porta sì, ch’i’ fu’ contento.
query.result:
**English:**
118 One was gold and the other was silver; 119 first with the white and then with the yellow 120 he did such things to the door that I was content.**Cornish:**
118 On o eur ha’n aral o aryant; 119 kyns gans an wenn ha wosa gans an melyn 120 y'n gorragh dhe'n fordh, bydhaf oen kalon.**

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
121 «Quandunque l’una d’este chiavi falla, 122 che non si volga dritta per la toppa», 123 diss’ elli a noi, «non s’apre questa calla.
query.result:
**English:**
121 “Whenever one of these keys fails, 122 so that it does not turn straight in the keyhole”, 123 he said to us, “this passage does not open.**Cornish:**
121 “Pandra veur onan a henna gelwys a-fya, 122 na wra dhe dhybri dhe-ugh an toll”, 123 leverel henna, “na wra dhegor an fordh ma.**

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
124 Più cara è l’una; ma l’altra vuol troppa 125 d’arte e d’ingegno avanti che diserri, 126 perch’ ella è quella che ’l nodo digroppa.
query.result:
**English:**
124 One is dearer; but the other requires too much 125 of art and ingenuity before it opens, 126 because it is the one that ties the knot.
**Cornish:**
124 Unn yw ker, mes an aral a vynna 125 a-lemmyn hag a-vedhel kyns na dhegor, 126 rag henna yw an unn a wrapp an golon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
127 Da Pier le tegno; e dissemi ch’i’ erri 128 anzi ad aprir ch’a tenerla serrata, 129 pur che la gente a’ piedi mi s’atterri».
query.result:
**English:**
127 From Pier I take it; and he told me that I was wrong 128 to open it rather than keep it closed, 129 provided that people would bow down to me.
**Cornish:**
127 Ganso Pier y’m gwiskas; ha leverys dhymm dh’ym oen 128 rag dhegor hy hy honna ser, 129 mar leverys an bobel omma dhymm.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
130 Poi pinse l’uscio a la porta sacrata, 131 dicendo: «Intrate; ma facciovi accorti 132 che di fuor torna chi ’n dietro si guata».
query.result:
**English:**
130 Then he pushed the door of the sacred gate, 131 saying: "Enter; but I warn you 132 that whoever looks back will be turned away."
**Cornish:**
130 Wosa henna an fordh dhe’n fordh sans, 131 leverel: “Ewch; mes warnav dh’euch 132 henna pyw hedho dhe’n fordh a welo dhe’n keffrys.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
133 E quando fuor ne’ cardini distorti 134 li spigoli di quella regge sacra, 135 che di metallo son sonanti e forti,
136 non rugghiò sì né si mostrò sì acra 137 Tarpëa, come tolto le fu il buono 138 Metello, per che poi rimase macra.
query.result:
**English:**
133 And when the pivots of that sacred gate, 134 the corners of which are of metal, resounding and strong, 135 were twisted out of their hinges,
136 Tarpeia did not roar so loudly or show herself so fierce 137 when the good Metellus was taken from her, 138 because of which she then remained barren.
**Cornish:**
133 Ha pan wosa dhe’n fordh dhe’n fordh sans 134 an pennow a henna kastel sans, 135 a-derivas a metal, sonorous ha kalet,
136 ny rugyas ken po ny wrug genen ken akra 137 Tarpëa, pan wosa kemerys dhe’n da 138 Metellus, rag henna hi remenas goos.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
139 Io mi rivolsi attento al primo tuono, 140 e ‘Te Deum laudamus’ mi parea 141 udire in voce mista al dolce suono.
query.result:
**English:**
139 I turned my attention to the first sound, 140 and it seemed to me that I heard 141 “Te Deum laudamus” mixed with the sweet sound.
**Cornish:**
139 Y’m droas dhe’m golon dhe’n kynsa sôn, 140 ha “Te Deum laudamus” a welas 141 ow kov dhe’n sôn melyon.
